content.content:
[Content truncated]...Story continues below advertisement
Dinco noted that officers “can’t treat \ as though it is a prank,” and have to respond to each call, like the one placed Tuesday morning, as if it is real. But Riverside police receive a couple of fake calls like these a year, and are very aware that “there’s a possibility \ could not be true,” he said.
Share this articleShare
The matter is under investigation, Dinco said. Police haven’t arrested anyone, and are working to uncover the identity of the caller. In the department’s experience, people who call in with a swatting attempt typically “use techniques to mask their identity” from police.
Swatting is a misdemeanor in California, thanks to a law that , Dinco said. It’s punishable with up to a year in jail. Swatters could face felony charges in cases where victims are injured, Dinco added. In this case, no one was hurt.

The “Damn, Daniel” meme was also the subject of  in recent days, claiming that the “Daniel” of the video was mugged and robbed, losing the white Vans mentioned in the video to criminals.
_This piece has been updated to include an interview with a spokesperson for the Riverside Police Department._
_**Correction:** This piece, citing local media accounts, originally stated that the swatting call was a 911 emergency call. Riverside police have since clarified that the call came into the department’s non-emergency line._

Teen who posted viral 'Damn Daniel' video victim of swatting
============================================================
Tuesday, February 23, 2016
!(blob:https://abc7.com/2fac3861d78e57572d62edf6f1d3fbe7)
The teenager who filmed the viral 'Damn Daniel' video and posted the clip on Twitter was the victim of a bogus emergency call that prompted police to swarm his family's Riverside home.
RIVERSIDE, Calif. (KABC) -- The teenager who filmed the viral "Damn Daniel" video and posted the clip on Twitter was the victim of a bogus emergency call that prompted police to swarm his family's Riverside home.
Police responded around 1 a.m. Tuesday after they received reports that someone at a residence on Hamilton Drive had shot their mother with an AK-47.
"A person called Riverside Police Department dispatch center and used some kind of a voice modification device and reported that he had shot his mother," Riverside police Lt. Kevin Townsend said.
The family cooperated with authorities, at which point police searched the home, cleared the scene and determined it was a false report.
"Swatting" refers to a prank in which someone convinces authorities to dispatch an emergency response for a fake incident. Many celebrities have been victims of swatting, including Lil Wayne, Justin Timberlake and Miley Cyrus.
Townsend said they've responded to a few swatting incidents that are usually spurred by revenge.
"They tend to be, for us, revenge in some way. Once we're able to track down who made the call, it's someone trying to get back at someone, whether it be an ex or something like that but that's what it seems like -- exes or teenagers," Townsend said.
The "Damn Daniel" video, which features a teenager following his friend around saying, "Damn, Daniel," has been retweeted...[Content truncated]

Like any news organization, it can sometimes present sensational stories, but overall, it maintains high standards in journalism.

Query2.title: Fran Magazine: Issue #114 - by Fran Hoepfner
Query2.snippet: Jul 10, 2024 ... There's a “Damn, Daniel”-esque quality to “Hawk Tuah” girl that I'm legitimately enjoying. Plus, it's funny she hung out with Shaq a day ...

content.content:
[Content truncated]...… so I am turning the reins over to my friend Harris Mayersohn for an in-depth convo of what you guys have missed while I’ve been pre-scheduling all the fantastic guest posts over the past few weeks.
This marks the first edition of the new (and hopefully infrequent) Fran Magazine segment: **Fran’s Crazy Life with Harris Mayersohn**. The idea being whenever something crazy happens to Fran, I’ll (Harris Mayersohn) interview her (Fran Hoepfner) about it (Crazy Thing).
**Hi Fran. I’d love to start by asking the question on everyone’s mind: What the hell is going on with your Crazy Life right now?**
Well, on Monday, July 1st, I was diagnosed with mononucleosis, or as it’s most commonly known, mono.
]
life rocks, etc.
**That’s Fran’s Crazy Life! Mono — some say that’s the kissing disease, right? Passed through saliva?**
Yes.
**Has me wondering, did you get mono from Hawk Tuah girl?**
No — given my limited access to the internet while in the Adirondacks, I resent that I know enough of who this is and her claim to spitting that I can refute this.
**There’s a “Damn, Daniel”-esque quality to “Hawk Tuah” girl that I’m legitimately enjoying. Plus, it’s funny she hung out with Shaq a day after going viral. Which brings me back to the topic at hand: How long do you think this mono will be staying around?**
Most people I know who have had it say it lasts between one and three months, which is to say if you thought you’d be seeing me in July, well, that’s probably not going to happen. I’d like to think that given my commitment to “chilling” and “not doing a ton of recreational drinking,” I’ll be able to beat it sooner than later, but everything I’ve read warns against trying to fight through it. You gotta just relinquish your life to the mono. At the time of our conversation, I’ve had it for maybe almost three weeks?
**This diagnosis was kind of a best - or maybe “better” - case scenario, right? We talked (off-record) in the run up to your medical discovery and there was a lot of uncertainty about what was going on.**
Not to, like, violate my own HIPAA or whatever, but this all started because one of the lymph nodes in my neck just got huge out of...[Content truncated]

Fran Magazine may provide insightful perspectives and niche content, but without organizational editorial standards, it cannot always be regarded as a reliable source for factual news or claims verification.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence mentions a 'Damn, Daniel' reference but does not address the claim about mugging or suggestions regarding shoe robbery. It is irrelevant to evaluating the claim.

Query2.title: The Mississippi Delta's History of Black Land Theft - The Atlantic
Query2.snippet: Sep 15, 2019 ... AgriVest, a subsidiary of the Swiss bank UBS, owned 22,000 acres as of 2011. (AgriVest did not respond to a request for more recent information.).

content.content:
[Content truncated]...burg. Fields stretch to the horizon. The hands that dig into black Delta dirt belong to people like Willena Scott-White, African Americans who bear faces and names passed down from men and women who were owned here, who were kept here, and who chose to stay here, tending the same fields their forebears tended.
But some things have changed. Back in the day, snow-white bolls of King Cotton reigned. Now much of the land is green with soybeans. The farms and plantations are much larger—industrial operations with bioengineered plants, laser-guided tractors, and crop-dusting drones. Fewer and fewer farms are still owned by actual farmers. Investors in boardrooms throughout the country have bought hundreds of thousands of acres of premium Delta land. If you’re one of the millions of people who have a retirement account with the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association, for instance, you might even own a little bit yourself.
TIAA is one of the largest pension firms in the United States. Together with its subsidiaries and associated funds, it has a portfolio of more than 80,000 acres in Mississippi alone, most of them in the Delta. If the fertile crescent of Arkansas is included, TIAA holds more than 130,000 acres in a strip of counties along the Mississippi River. And TIAA is not the only big corporate landlord in the region. Hancock Agricultural Investment Group manages more than 65,000 acres in what it calls the “Delta states.” The real-estate trust Farmland Partners has 30,000 acres in and around the Delta. AgriVest, a subsidiary of the Swiss bank UBS, owned 22,000 acres as of 2011. (AgriVest did not respond to a request for more recent information.)
Unlike their counterparts even two or three generations ago, black people living and working in the Delta today have been almost completely uprooted from the soil—as property owners, if not as laborers. In Washington County, Mississippi, where last February TIAA reportedly bought 50,000 acres for more than $200 million, black people make up 72 percent of the population but own only 11 percent of the farmland, in part or in full. In Tunica County, where TIAA has acquired plantations from some of the oldest farm-owning white families in the state, black people make up 77 percent of the population but own only 6 percent of the farmland. In Holmes County, the...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The Atlantic is a well-respected publication known for its rigorous journalism and in-depth analysis. It has a strong reputation for fact-checking and presents well-researched articles. The Atlantic is less likely to spread misinformation, making it a credible source for verifying claims about news events.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses land ownership and historical context but has no connection to the incident involving 'Damn Daniel.' It is completely irrelevant to the claim of mugging.

QA.Question: Does the video evidence support or contradict the claim that 'Damn Daniel' was mugged and robbed of his shoes?
QA.Answer: The video evidence does not support the claim that 'Damn Daniel' was mugged and robbed of his shoes. Instead, the available evidence indicates that such reports are likely hoaxes and viral misinformation. According to a report from Business Insider, the claim that Daniel Lara was robbed for his sneakers was not true. It specifically mentions that the reports of him being hospitalized after being beaten and robbed were propagated by a satire website and were not factual. Additionally, the Washington Post highlights that there were claims circulating on social media about the 'Damn Daniel' meme, suggesting that he had been mugged. However, these claims appear to be part of a larger discussion around misinformation and have not been substantiated by credible sources. ABC7 provides context about the type of prank known as "swatting," which the creator of 'Damn Daniel' became a victim of—but does not mention any incident involving mugging or robbery of shoes. This supports the idea that misinformation was spreading rather than actual events occurring regarding theft. In summary, the evidence clearly indicates that the claim of Daniel being mugged and robbed of his shoes is unfounded and likely a product of misinformation.
